title: Justice That We Can Trust with Tracey Meares and Tom Tyler - Initiative for Digital Public Infrastructure

last_post.content: We've got a new episode of Reimagining the Internet up today, an interview with Tracey Meares and Tom Tyler of Yale Law about their work on "procedural justice". Procedural justice tries to make justice systems - offline and online - work better by ensuring people's voices are heard and that they're treated with dignity. It's got big implications for online governance as well as for criminal justice reform: https://publicinfrastructure.org/podcast/tracey-meares-tom-tyler/

title: Napoléon Part I - From Corsica to Paris - La Fayette, We Are Here!

last_post.content:
#OTD in 1807, pyrrhic and indecisive French victory at the battle of Eylau, against the Russians and Prussians. The losses are so horrible that Napoléon stated: “If all the kings of the earth could view such a spectacle, they would be less keen on wars and conquest”.

One of the most remarkable moments of the battle was Murat’s cavalry charge. At 12,000 strong, it is one of the biggest cavalry charges ever. It was essential in preventing a French collapse during the battle. Nevertheless, Ney will say “What a massacre! And all this for nothing!”

The war will drag on for months. Only the decisive French victory of Friedland in June 1807 will lead to the treaty of Tilsit with Alexander I a month later, ending the war of the 4th Coalition and making Russia France’s partner in the continental system… for a time anyway.

To learn more about Napoléon’s rise to power, listen to our latest episode.

Listen on: https://www.lafayettepodcast.com/1969630/12142936-napoleon-part-i-from-corsica-to-paris

title: [experiment] Run babel over output for let/const to var by jakebailey · Pull Request #52656 · microsoft/TypeScript

last_post.content:
An excellent JS performance experiment by @jakebailey ⚡

Modifying the TypeScript compiler itself so that `let`/`const` become `var` reduces parsing time by ~10% 😲

This is on V8 10.2

One theory is that the perf penalty is due to TDZ checks when using `let`/`const`

Maybe results in Bun/JSC will be different?

Nothing is conclusive. The PR is unlikely to be merged.

The investigation continues... 😉

Big data visualization is about quoting less-aggregated data.

This network can be seen without 3D glasses. But with it, by just blinking, you can switch from the aggregated annotation layer to the less-aggregated original data, a network of expressions from academic papers about AI in science.

You can look "inside" the aggregation, and possibly challenge it. The same way quoting a text allows the reader to challenge what *you* say it says.

Reminder that by default, mastodon.social allows search engines to crawl the site. https://mastodon.social/robots.txt limits only two resources by default:

User-agent: *
Disallow: /media_proxy/
Disallow: /interact/

But each of the user accounts have additional settings for search visibility, so it's a lot more complex than just allowing everything. Besides of that, CDN etc. on front of the service likely has additional limitations and filtering for reducing potential issues. But it could be a lot better.

title: AI Art and the Problem of Consent

last_post.content:
"AI Art and the Problem of Consent" is a great piece by Mat Dryhurst, in the Art Review. Reads almost like a manifesto.

https://artreview.com/ai-art-and-the-problem-of-consent/

"The polar ideologies of free culture or rigid IP protectionism of the last century feel insufficient for tackling an issue that promises to mutate into a long culture war." writes Mat. And argues that consent is the missing bit.

This is something that we have been studying at @openfuture with regard to the use of photos of faces in face recognition training. This is structurally a similar conversation, only concerning creative outputs instead of visages (there's an interesting overlap between the two, by the way).

Yet while in our case the answer we heard very quickly was "this is not a copyright issue", what Mat writes about is a case that will reopen all key copyright debates: on fair use, exceptions, user rights, remuneration of artists.

And I would argue with Mat that free culture offers a good foundation for tackling the issue. Though I agree that it needs to expand its toolkit. But the vision of a digital, creative commons still holds true.

A new "open-source tool that converts any music-library into a sample-library with machine learning. It separates songs into stems, quantizes to same BPM, detects key and much more."

This seems like YA example of how the last N decades of #sampling, #mashups, etc (and that's just in music) should be seen in retrospect as the artisanal "primitive accumulation" phase of whatever hyperautomation will bring.

If everyone's going to talk about how "revolutionary" this, "game-changing" that, and "epistemic abyss" the other, that's all just historical periodization, isn't it? It *should* inaugurate a golden age of #historiography. Except that #capitalism (or, per @Mckenzie, "something worse") doesn't like historiography, because it offers one of the few conceptual ladders out of its totalizing nonsense.

title: There Are No Markets Anymore | Transnational Institute

last_post.content:
#BigTech #Markets #Oligopolies #Neofeudalism #Neoliberalism: "Market design has underpinned the ascendance of Big Tech firms over the last decade or so. A new array of digital and algorithmic technologies have enabled these and other data-driven firms to monetise the very information on which markets are supposedly dependent (e.g. who wants to buy X, what person Y would pay for Z, how many people view A); this market information is meant to be transparent and truthful to ensure competition, but it is increasingly hoarded and hidden in data enclaves constructed by Big Tech firms to secure their monopolistic positions. So, rather than simply monetising personal information, Big Tech firms have gone far beyond the ‘surveillance’ fears of many critical thinkers, such as Shoshana Zuboff(external link).

Today, however, Big Tech firms face challenges on different fronts: from politicians and policy-makers developing new frameworks to curtail their power; and from the internal contradictions and dysfunctions in their own operations. All of this raises the question: will markets come back with a vengeance, or is this the start of something new? An important point for activists, civil society groups, non-government organisations (NGOs), and publics to remember when raising awareness or engaging with governments about the power of Big Tech is that if there are no longer any markets, then regulators returning to their outdated ways of understanding the world to rein in Big Tech will not work. We have to think beyond the market."

https://www.tni.org/en/article/there-are-no-markets-anymore
